node.title: The Crypto Company Behind the Renaming of the Los Angeles Staples Center
node.alt: Kris Marszalek, chief executive of Crypto.com, in 2018. In an interview, he called Staples Center, the Los Angeles sports venue that his company has secured naming rights to, “culturally relevant.”
node.description: What’s Crypto.com, which is paying $700 million for the naming rights to the sports venue?
node.content: ["LOS ANGELES \u2014 Less than four years ago, Crypto.com was the personal blog of a University of Pennsylvania computer science professor.", "By the end of this year, the name will be emblazoned on one of the most storied U.S. sports venues, part of an expensive marketing blitz from a little-known company that took over the web address and turned the site into a cryptocurrency playground.", "That company, which was founded as a start-up named Monaco in 2016, is a cryptocurrency exchange that also offers digital wallets and crypto-backed debit cards. Its has its headquarters in Singapore but maintains addresses in Malta, the United Kingdom and Ireland. Its chief executive, who is also its majority shareholder, previously ran a failed daily deals site for Southeast Asia. The company is privately held and has raised no institutional funding.", "Yet this week, Crypto.com, which billed itself as \u201cthe world\u2019s fastest-growing cryptocurrency platform,\u201d said it had secured the naming rights for 20 years to Staples Center in Los Angeles. The venue will be renamed Crypto.com Arena on Dec. 25. The deal cost about $700 million, said two people with knowledge of the details, one of the largest sums ever paid for a sporting venue\u2019s naming rights.", "The deal punctuated how the world of cryptocurrencies has been on a tear over the past year, minting millionaires, spawning a slew of new buzzwords (web3, NFTs, DAOs) and attracting investment from more than 20 million people in the United States alone, according to one survey. On Thursday, a group of cryptocurrency fans amassed more than $40 million to bid for a rare original copy of the U.S. Constitution.", "And as interest in cryptocurrencies soars \u2014 the price of Bitcoin has jumped nearly 230 percent in the last 12 months to around $60,000 a coin \u2014 companies like Crypto.com are vying for attention among the general public.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a symbol of how mainstream crypto has gone,\u201d said Laura Shin, an author whose podcast about cryptocurrencies, \u201cUnchained,\u201d has run Crypto.com ads. \u201cThis whole past year, a lot of what the crypto people call \u2018normies\u2019 have entered the space.\u201d", "Ms. Shin said she was not surprised by Crypto.com\u2019s naming rights deal. \u201cThis is the story of every crypto person: They started with a small amount of money, and now they\u2019re gazillionaires,\u201d she said.", "In its original incarnation as Monaco, the company offered branded Visa debit cards that could be topped up using cryptocurrencies. It raised funding by minting its own digital token and selling it to the public in 2017 in an initial coin offering, a form of crowdfunding that is similar to an initial public offering. The company\u2019s balance sheet stood at nearly $200 million as of mid-2018, Kris Marszalek, the chief executive, told the blog TechCrunch at the time.", "It was then, during a slump in cryptocurrency prices, that Mr. Marszalek decided to rebrand Monaco. He contacted Matt Blaze, a cryptography professor then at the University of Pennsylvania, who had owned the crypto.com domain name for 25 years. During that time, Mr. Blaze had refused to part with the web address and had publicly disdained the new digital gold rush.", "But this time, Mr. Blaze couldn\u2019t resist. In a July 2018 blog post, he wrote that he had \u201cgotten a growing barrage of offers, many of which were obviously nonserious, but a few of which were, frankly, attention-getting, for the crypto.com domain.\u201d He said he had \u201cshrugged most of them off, but it became increasingly clear that holding on to the domain was making less and less sense for me.\u201d", "Mr. Blaze, now a professor at Georgetown University, declined to comment. In a Zoom interview from a stark white room in Hong Kong, Mr. Marszalek also declined to discuss what he paid for the Crypto.com domain name, but pointed to an article on the tech site The Verge that suggested the address could be worth millions.", "In an interview, Mr. Marszalek, 42, a Polish-born entrepreneur, said Crypto.com and its parent company, Foris Technology, had their headquarters in Singapore. Crypto.com\u2019s trading app, which allows people to buy and sell Bitcoin, Ether and 150 other digital currencies, makes money by taking a fee on transactions. Mr. Marszalek said the company was profitable but did not provide exact figures.", "\u201cAs with all cryptocurrency businesses this year, the market has been phenomenal,\u201d he said. He added that Crypto.com\u2019s revenue between April and June was about a quarter of that of Coinbase, a leading cryptocurrency exchange, which generated $2.2 billion in revenue in that period.", "Crypto.com is only the ninth-largest cryptocurrency exchange by daily volume, according to CoinMarketCap, a site that tracks cryptocurrency trading and prices. Yet the bull market has allowed the company to fund an eye-popping marketing push.", "It recently signed sports sponsorship deals with the United Fighting Championship, Formula 1 Racing and Italy\u2019s Serie A soccer league, as well as sports teams including the Paris St.-Germain soccer team in France and the Philadelphia 76ers. Crypto.com\u2019s website features a David Fincher-produced, Matt Damon-led advertisement with astronauts, telling customers that \u201cfortune favors the brave.\u201d", "Those moves have given Crypto.com \u201cadditional visibility,\u201d Mr. Marszalek said, noting that he\u2019s a basketball fan who loved Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls. And even though he had never been to Staples Center, the \u201cdeal is even more significant because of the legacy of this place,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s culturally relevant.\u201d", "Whether the company will have staying power over the 20 years of its naming rights deal is unclear. Another cryptocurrency exchange, FTX, bought the naming rights to the home arena of the Miami Heat this year, in a bet that crypto is now mainstream.", "Yet history is littered with stadium naming deals gone bad. Enron, the energy company, secured the naming rights to the Houston Astros\u2019 stadium in 1999 before it collapsed two years later and removed its name from the venue. In 2000, CMGI, a dot-com incubator, got the naming rights to the New England Patriots\u2019 new football stadium in Foxboro, Mass. \u2014 and then fell from grace shortly thereafter in the dot-com crash.", "Staples, the office supply store chain whose name Crypto.com is displacing in Los Angeles, hasn\u2019t fared much better. It signed its naming deal for the venue in 1997 with AEG, the sports and live entertainment company controlled by the billionaire Philip F. Anschutz. Its business has since been decimated by the advent of online shopping, and it sold the Staples Center naming rights back to AEG in 2019.", "Dan Beckerman, AEG\u2019s chief executive, said he didn\u2019t think Crypto.com would go the way of Staples.", "\u201cWe believe it\u2019s viable, long term, and they will be around a lot longer than all of us,\u201d he said. "]
